messages.text:
I'm having a problem with MonteCarloMeasurements.jl and I can't tell what I'm doing wrong. I noticed that between runs the values returned for mean() and std() for my particles vary wildly, no matter how many particles I use. Here's an example code:
```function f()
    m_multiplet1 = 0.545 + 0.065*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    b_multiplet1 = -5.69 + 0.076*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    m_multiplet2 = 0.442 + 0.036*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    b_multiplet2 = -6.4 + 0.11*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    y_values = vcat([m_multiplet1*x + b_multiplet1 for x in 1:30], [m_multiplet2*x + b_multiplet2 for x in 1:30])
    y_median = @unsafe median(y_values)
    x_multiplet1_median = (y_median - b_multiplet1)/m_multiplet1
    x_multiplet2_median = (y_median - b_multiplet2)/m_multiplet2
    Δ = @unsafe x_multiplet1_median > x_multiplet2_median ? x_multiplet1_median - x_multiplet2_median : x_multiplet2_median - x_multiplet1_median
    Δχ = 2.0722916666666669
    Texc = 5040*Δχ/Δ
    println("m_multiplet1: $m_multiplet1 b_multiplet1: $b_multiplet1")
    println("m_multiplet2: $m_multiplet2 b_multiplet2: $b_multiplet2")
    println("y_median: $y_median")
    println("x_multiplet1_median: $x_multiplet1_median")
    println("x_multiplet2_median: $x_multiplet2_median")
    println("Δ: $Δ")
    println("Δχ: $Δχ")
    println("Texc: $Texc")
end```
(more in comment)

elements.text: I'm having a problem with MonteCarloMeasurements.jl and I can't tell what I'm doing wrong. I noticed that between runs the values returned for mean() and std() for my particles vary wildly, no matter how many particles I use. Here's an example code:

function f()
    m_multiplet1 = 0.545 + 0.065*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    b_multiplet1 = -5.69 + 0.076*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    m_multiplet2 = 0.442 + 0.036*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    b_multiplet2 = -6.4 + 0.11*Particles(MONTE_CARLO_NUM_SAMPLES)
    y_values = vcat([m_multiplet1*x + b_multiplet1 for x in 1:30], [m_multiplet2*x + b_multiplet2 for x in 1:30])
    y_median = @unsafe median(y_values)
    x_multiplet1_median = (y_median - b_multiplet1)/m_multiplet1
    x_multiplet2_median = (y_median - b_multiplet2)/m_multiplet2
    Δ = @unsafe x_multiplet1_median > x_multiplet2_median ? x_multiplet1_median - x_multiplet2_median : x_multiplet2_median - x_multiplet1_median
    Δχ = 2.0722916666666669
    Texc = 5040*Δχ/Δ
    println("m_multiplet1: $m_multiplet1 b_multiplet1: $b_multiplet1")
    println("m_multiplet2: $m_multiplet2 b_multiplet2: $b_multiplet2")
    println("y_median: $y_median")
    println("x_multiplet1_median: $x_multiplet1_median")
    println("x_multiplet2_median: $x_multiplet2_median")
    println("Δ: $Δ")
    println("Δχ: $Δχ")
    println("Texc: $Texc")
end

messages.text:
When I try to assert the input argument with `::Function` , I found something that confused me a lot. Here is the example:
```f(x) = x + 1;
f2(x) = x + 2;
g(f::Function, x) = 1*f(x);
g(f_array::Array{Function,1}, x) = [1*f_array[1](x), -1*f_array[2](x)];```
For `g([f,f],1)`, it returns error:
```ERROR: MethodError: no method matching g(::Array{typeof(f),1}, ::Int64)
Closest candidates are:
  g(::Function, ::Any) at REPL[3]:1
  g(::Array{Function,1}, ::Any) at REPL[4]:1
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[7]:1```
However, it is OK with `g([f,f2],1)`
it returns
```2-element Array{Int64,1}:
  2
 -3```
I'm curious about the reason and what should I modify my code to allow `g([f,f],x)` , with type assertion that make sure the first input argument is an array of function.

Can someone explain for me, or provide me some keywords that I can find the answer myself?
Thanks in advance.

messages.text:
eh, I wonder why redefine `Base.:+` can work, but these won't be work
```Base.:¬(p::Bool) = !p # negative
Base.:∧(p::Bool, q::Bool) = p && q #conjunction
Base.:∨(p::Bool, q::Bool) = p || q #disjunction
Base.:→(p::Bool, q::Bool) = begin #implication
  !(p == true && q == false)
end

Base.:↔(p::Bool, q::Bool) = p == q #equivalence```
can you help me out ??

messages.text:
I’m struggling with a basic optional or nullable representation, essentially I have the following:

```mutable struct Wrapper
   value::Union{Int64, Nothing}
end

w = Wrapper(nothing)```
Then I have a function that performs an IO operation and sets the value for further reuse, I’m not getting the function to work, its something like this:

```function some_io_op(); 10 end
function set_value!(w::Wrapper)::Int64
   if w.value != Some(nothing)
      return w.value::Int64
   end

   # Perform operation
   value = some_io_op()
   w.value = value
   return value
end```
When I try the above I get the following error:

```  TypeError: in typeassert, expected Int64, got a value of type Nothing```
I found <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/faq/#faq-nothing|the following> but can’t seem to figure out an example, any help is appreciated

messages.text: hi all! i have a couple of functions that contain a lot of recursive calls to each other, some of them have multiple methods. it's about 500 lines of code. compilation took something like 15 minutes on 1.5, and since i updated to 1.6 i  have not yet seen it terminate. execution (on 1.5) was super fast. i used MLStyle.jl @match, which afaiu generates even more multi-method functions; replacing some of the @match'es improved things a bit but even 15 minutes is a lot of minutes for not that much code. i remember reading something about the typechecker struggling with recursion in some cases? any other ideas?

messages.text: Hello, I'm getting some issues with the package compiling of an NLP-related project. The issue is a huge dynamic library generated after PackageCompiler. gcc-linker in MacOS is not able to link properly more than 2GB library. I created an issue <https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl/issues/500> with a really simple project which is reproducing it, but still no reaction. The project uses Embeddings, Flux, Transformers packages, and maybe that is an issue. Any thoughts on how to work around it?

messages.text:
hi everyone! I am currently using my self-defined method to create block-diagonal matrices on the fly:
```blkdiagm(A::Matrix, B::Matrix) = [A zeros(size(A,1), size(B,2)); zeros(size(B,1), size(A,2)) B]
blkdiagm(A::Matrix... ) = blkdiagm(A[1], blkdiagm(A[2:end]...))```
the issue, is that this definition seems to become a bottleneck with larger problems and I am not quite sure - it seems to be the concatanation. (In most cases I only use the 2-argument one).

So I guess the best option is to instead do
```C = zeros(m1+m2, n1+n2)
C[1:m1,1:n1] .= A
C[m1+1:end,n1+1:end] .= B```
is there a better way? any suggestions?

elements.text: hi everyone! I am currently using my self-defined method to create block-diagonal matrices on the fly:

blkdiagm(A::Matrix, B::Matrix) = [A zeros(size(A,1), size(B,2)); zeros(size(B,1), size(A,2)) B]
blkdiagm(A::Matrix... ) = blkdiagm(A[1], blkdiagm(A[2:end]...))

the issue, is that this definition seems to become a bottleneck with larger problems and I am not quite sure - it seems to be the concatanation. (In most cases I only use the 2-argument one).

So I guess the best option is to instead do

C = zeros(m1+m2, n1+n2)
C[1:m1,1:n1] .= A
C[m1+1:end,n1+1:end] .= B
is there a better way? any suggestions?

messages.text: Hi. I am trying to Port C++ program to Julia, but facing some difficulties with float type accuracy. In c++ double float type operation 19.92-0.02 results in 19.9. In Julia Float64 same operation results in 19.900000000000002. what's the best way in Julia to align it to C++ float behavior?

messages.text:
I've had some discussion <https://julialang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/225542-helpdesk/topic/Package.20in.20Bare.20Git.20Repository|over on Zulip> but thought I would ask here as well as we ran out of our collective knowledge of Git/Pkg/Windows.

The primary question boils down to, can you `Pkg.add("mypackage")` where you give a local filepath to a bare git repo? I am thinking more and more that Pkg doesn't handle this case but perhaps I could be doing something incorrectly.

If this is indeed impossible how do other folks add a package hosted on a shared network drive? I know I can `git -clone` the package to a local folder and add that but seems like an unnecessary step.
Maybe the solution I'm looking for is a local registry or something...but I can't make heads or tails of the documents in localregistry.jl

messages.text:
Does GR.jl have a persistent state? If I run this code in two different Julia sessions, the second session is faster:
```   _       _ _(_)_     |  Documentation: <https://docs.julialang.org>
  (_)     | (_) (_)    |
   _ _   _| |_  __ _   |  Type "?" for help, "]?" for Pkg help.
  | | | | | | |/ _` |  |
  | | |_| | | | (_| |  |  Version 1.6.0 (2021-03-24)
 _/ |\__'_|_|_|\__'_|  |  Official <https://julialang.org/> release
|__/                   |

julia> @time begin
           import GR, Random
           Random.seed!(37)
           y = randn(20, 501)

           GR.setviewport(0.1, 0.95, 0.1, 0.95)
           GR.setcharheight(0.020)
           GR.settextcolorind(82)
           GR.setfillcolorind(90)
           GR.setfillintstyle(1)

           let x = 1
               GR.clearws()
               GR.setwindow(x, x+500, -200, 200)
               GR.fillrect(x, x+500, -200, 200)
               GR.setlinecolorind(0);  GR.grid(50, 50, 0, -200, 2, 2)
               GR.setlinecolorind(82); GR.axes(50, 50, x, -200, 2, 2, -0.005)
               for i in 1:20
                   GR.setlinecolorind(980 + i)
                   s = cumsum(reshape(y[i,:], x+500))
                   GR.polyline([x:x+500;], s[x:x+500])
               end
               GR.updatews()
           end
       end
  0.463608 seconds (574.50 k allocations: 36.339 MiB, 1.38% gc time, 0.69% compilation time)```

elements.text: Does GR.jl have a persistent state? If I run this code in two different Julia sessions, the second session is faster:

release
|__/                   |

julia> @time begin
           import GR, Random
           Random.seed!(37)
           y = randn(20, 501)

           GR.setviewport(0.1, 0.95, 0.1, 0.95)
           GR.setcharheight(0.020)
           GR.settextcolorind(82)
           GR.setfillcolorind(90)
           GR.setfillintstyle(1)

           let x = 1
               GR.clearws()
               GR.setwindow(x, x+500, -200, 200)
               GR.fillrect(x, x+500, -200, 200)
               GR.setlinecolorind(0);  GR.grid(50, 50, 0, -200, 2, 2)
               GR.setlinecolorind(82); GR.axes(50, 50, x, -200, 2, 2, -0.005)
               for i in 1:20
                   GR.setlinecolorind(980 + i)
                   s = cumsum(reshape(y[i,:], x+500))
                   GR.polyline([x:x+500;], s[x:x+500])
               end
               GR.updatews()
           end
       end
  0.463608 seconds (574.50 k allocations: 36.339 MiB, 1.38% gc time, 0.69% compilation time)

messages.text: Say I have an array of arrays of values (say floats) `vv::Vector{Vector{Float64}}`, and another array `a::Vector{Float64}` of same length such that all elements of `vv[i]`  are between `a[i-1]`  and `a[i]` . Now, I want a method `all_less_than(k::Float64)` that gives me the elements in each array of `vv`  less than `k` . I can return all `vv[i]` with `a[i]<k` directly, but for the last index `i` , I have to filter through the vector `vv[i]` . It would return something like a subvector of `vv` _plus_ a view over the last `vv[i]` . Is there a way to make it into a nice vector or something?

messages.text:
If I have two vectors `a = [1,2,3]` and `b = [4,5,6]` and I want a vector of vectors of their values i.e. I want `[[1,4], [2,5], [3,6]]`  what is a good way to accomplish that?
I tried `[[x,y] for x in a, y in b]` but that results in a 4x4 matrix of all the combinations. I also tried `collect(zip(a,b))` but that gives tuples not vectors.
